TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic Aquic Argicryolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Leroux loam - woodland.  (colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
Oi--3 inches to 0; mat of slightly decomposed needles, twigs, and leaves.
A1--0 to 4 inches; brown (7.5YR 4/2) loam, dark brown (7.5YR 3/2) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure parting to moderate fine and medium granular; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; 5 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles, 1 percent stones; neutral (pH 6.8); clear smooth boundary.
A2--4 to 11 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/2) loam, dark brown (7.5YR 3/2) moist; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; 5 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles, one percent stones; slightly acid; (pH 6.4) clear smooth boundary.  (Combined thickness is 10 to 20 inches)
Bt1--11 to 22 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/3) clay loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, sticky and plastic; many faint clay films on faces of peds; 5 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles, one percent stones; moderately acid (pH 5.8); clear smooth boundary.  (10 to 12 inches thick)
Bt2--22 to 31 inches; light reddish brown (5YR 6/3) clay, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; strong fine and medium subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; many faint clay films on faces of peds; 5 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles, one percent stones; strongly acid (pH 5.4); clear wavy boundary.  (6 to 14 inches thick)
BCt--31 to 38 inches; light reddish brown (5YR 6/4) sandy clay, reddish brown (5YR 5/3) moist; massive; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; common faint clay films on faces of peds; common, medium and coarse, distinct and prominent, yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) redox concentrations; 5 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles, one percent stones; strongly acid (pH 5.4); clear wavy boundary.  (6 to 10 inches thick)
C--38 to 48 inches; light brown (7.5YR 6/4) clay, brown (7.5YR 5/3) moist; massive; hard, friable, sticky and plastic; common, medium and coarse, distinct and prominent, yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) redox concentrations; 5 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles, one percent stones; strongly acid (pH 5.4); clear wavy boundary.  (8 to 12 inches thick)
2C--48 to 60 inches; very pale brown (10YR 8/2) stratified clay loam and fine sandy loam, light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) moist; massive; hard to soft, friable to soft, slightly sticky to nonsticky and nonplastic to plastic; common, medium and coarse, distinct and prominent, yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) redox concentrations; 5 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles; strongly acid (pH 5.4).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Delta County, Colorado; on Leroux Creek road in the SE1/4 of the SE1/4 of Sec. 19, T. 12 S., R. 92 W.  Latitude:  38 degrees, 59 minutes, 23 seconds N.; Longitude:  107 degrees, 42 minutes, 23 seconds W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 38 to 43 degrees F.  Average summer soil temperature ranges from 44 to 47 degrees F.  The mollic epipedon is 10 to 20 inches thick.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 15 percent and are typically pebble and cobble in size.  The soil is saturated for 3 months or more during the spring and summer.  Mottles are medium to coarse, distinct and prominent (10YR 5/6) at depths of 30 inches or more.
The A horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 4 or 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist and chroma of 2 or 3.  Reaction is slightly acid to neutral.
The Bt horizons have hue of 10YR through 5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist and chroma of 3 to 4.  It is clay loam, clay  or sandy clay with 35 to 55 percent clay.  Reaction is strongly acid or moderately acid.
The C horizons have hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 6 through 8 dry, 5 or 6 moist and chroma of 2 through 4.  Reaction is strongly to moderately acid.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There currently are no other competing series in this family.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Leroux soils are on mountain and valley side slopes.  Slopes range from 5 to 40 percent.  Elevation ranges from 8,600 to 10,200 feet.  Mean annual precipitation is 26 to 32 inches.  The mean annual temperature is 34 to 40 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Seitz, Behanin, and Doughspon soils.  Seitz and Behanin soils are well drained.  Seitz, Behanin, and Doughspon soils have greater than 35 percent coarse fragments in the particle-size control section.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Moderately well drained; medium to rapid runoff; slow permeability.  A water table is at 2 to 3 feet during the period April to July.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  This soil is used for timber production, livestock grazing, wildlife habitat, and recreation.  In Colorado it is in the Engelmann spruce-Subalpine fir woodland site.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  West central Colorado.  The series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED:  Delta County (Grand Mesa-West Elk Soil Survey Area) Colorado, 1988.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  This soil is named after Leroux Creek in the Grand Mesa National Forest.  Diagnostic features include a mollic epipedon, the zone from 0 to 11 inches, an argillic horizon, the zone from 11 to 31 inches, and aquic feature, saturated continuously for 3 months or more within 40 inches.  Last updated by the state 6/93.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
